title.narrative: Enhancing Peace, Stability, and Poverty Reduction along the Ethiopia-South Sudan Border

description.narrative: 1. Increased level of implementation of local agreements, decreased dowry levels and increased mutual respect and cooperation in various projects among the tribes and clans living in the targeted areas of Gambella, with special attention for the role of women and of youth. 2. Inclusive improved food security through increased availability and optimal and collaborative use of available livelihood resources and increased services among the various tribes and clans living in the targeted areas of Gambella, with special attention for the role of women and of youth.

Internally Displaced Communities and their hosting communities in Wantawo and Akobo Woredas of Gambella Regional State, Ethiopia. Total amount of beneficiaries: around 50,000 people (about 8,300 households).
To enhance stability and safety as preconditions for people to rebuild their lives and strengthen their livelihood strategies.

participating-org.narrative: Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs (DGIS) / The Dutch Embassy in Ethiopia

activity-date.narrative: No cost extension has been granted for January - June 2016

description.narrative: Revised final agreement

transaction.ref: Total Expenditures under this activity until end of project

description.narrative: Improved capacity for enhanced household productivity in agriculture and fishing.

By the end of the project, at least 25% of beneficiary households engaged in agriculture in target communities have added one crop to their portfolio (households having improved access to land) or have added at least one seed variety (households having limited access to land) over the baseline.

comment.narrative: Description: Sorghum & Maize
2-days workshop was held by trainer of DPFA for 16 participants of different government bureaus and traditional leaders.
37.6% of households that grow their own crops added a new crop last year. 27.9% of households that grow their own crops added a new seed variety last year.

Sorghum and Maize were distributed in 2013 and 2014 and no new crop or new variety was introduced. This was agreed upon with the Regional Agricultural Bureau and the beneficiaries. For 2015 it is planned to target flooding affected households in Akobo with additional seed supply

description.narrative: By the end of the project, average crop production of beneficiary households in target communities has increased by 10% over baseline.

comment.narrative: Nuer Jikany - maize production: 319 kilo/HH; sorghum production: 176 kilo/HH. Anyuak - maize production: 174 kilo/HH; sorghum production: 177 kilo/HH.
83 community members (32 female) of the different sub-clans, mainly from Gagwang, Gajok and Anuak, received improved agricultural traning.

Due to excessive flooding most of the farmers lost their crops in 2014. During a survey done in February it was reported that on average the HH harvested 389 kg maize and 299 kg sorghum. This contradicts with the information we received earlier from the Agricultural Office and from observation reports. In 2015 we will work on more reliable production monitoring.

Maize production grew with 11.8% over baseline. Sorghum production grew with 5.3% over baseline. This is only measured for Nuer (Jikany and Lou), Anuak households could not be interviewed in 2016 since they were all evacuated from the two woredas due to conflict.

description.narrative: Improved capacity of local government in 2 Woredas to facilitate stakeholders in the target areas to develop capacity in community cohesion for the outputs 1.1 and 1.2.

By the end of the project at least 50 government and partner staff who have participated in the training, report back on examples of successful application of improved community cohesion skills (this includes initial early warning systems against cattle raiding).

comment.narrative: N/A

Government staff have been involved in community cohesion activities. Overall everyone who we spoke to and who attended one of the trainings reported back they learned what community cohesion means, how they can talk with others about it and how to aware others. However, not enough evidence was gathered to know what 50 government and partner staff report back from the training. Different meetings are held for Justice Bureau and other government staff. High turnover of government staff is a problem.

Under USAID funding: Government staff (especially Justice Bureau and Justice Office: 8) staff is part of the implementation of the project. The indication is that the staff has improved capacity. However this is not measured yet. In 2015 with BUZA funding 30 government staff will be trained on community cohesion and 20 government staff will be joining the CC-agreements monitoring visits which contains training
Will be implemented by JB in 2014-2016

description.narrative: Improved capacity of relevant local tribal and clan leaders, churches, other organizations and local government to prevent and mitigate issues and sustain community cohesion and to address underlying contributors to instability.
By the end of the project, youth are actively included in at least 40% of inter-group resolution efforts in the targeted areas

comment.narrative: During the baseline survey the youth was not involved in inter-group resolution efforts/ community cohesion agreements.

For USAID in 2014 youth were included, however during signing of agreements and by tracking down the CCLC members on woreda and kebele level the age of the person was not written down. This will be improved in 2015 as well for the implementation of BUZA activities.

Youth groups come together in Wanthoa and Akobo Woreda. Youth are members of CCLCs. And youth are involved in Sport 4 Unity, sport teams to create cohesion in the Woredas. However, it is not possible to say whether the inclusion is up to 40%.
Youth stigmatized as gangsters identified and involved in livelihood and sports activities. This output is implemented by JB in 2014 - 2016.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, functional systems are in place in all targeted counties/Woreda to follow up on local/regional community cohesion agreements.

comment.narrative: Reference point is one peace committee (Nuer Council of Churches) at time of baseline study.

In 2014 funded by USAID in each kebele (12), five community cohesion working groups with each 40 members (total 2400 members M1278/F1122), one kebele community cohesion leadership committee (KCCLC) is established. In both woredas a woreda community cohesion leadership committee is functional. For BUZA/EKN this will be done in 2015 for 17 kebeles in Wanthoa and 15 kebeles in Akobo.
LoU signed with the Regional Justice Bureau (JB) for implementation of all community cohesion activities.

Woreda CCLCs in Akobo and Wanthoa, Kebele CCLCs in different Kebeles, CC Facilitators follow up and report to ZOA and Justice Bureau. Women groups and youth groups raise awareness in Kebeles. CC Working Group is in place in Wanthoa.

description.narrative: By the end of the project 50% of targeted communities have developed initial early warning systems against cattle raiding

comment.narrative: The Early Warning System does not function anymore

Early Warning System training is carried out in June 2016. Traditional Early Warning Systems are in place. People know who to warn in case of a problem/conflict. Key persons are trained about TEWS, and will disseminate the knowledge in the communities. Traditionally TEWS are in place and are used by people.
Is planned for 2015, see adjusted plan for 2015
Will be worked on by JB in 2014-2016

description.narrative: By the end of the project 100 tribal leaders, church leaders, youth group / association leaders, women group / association leaders and local government staff capacitated to lead discussions and organise campaigns for making dowry prices and debts more manageable and adjusting bylaws.

comment.narrative: In 2014 funded by USAID the two Woreda Community Cohesion Leadership Committees (60 members) were trained to lead discussions and organise campaigns. These members include pastors, youth, women and local leaders. For BUZA in 2015 this set up of WCCLC will be followed and members capacitated. Besides this 4 Justice Bureau staff and 4 Justice Office staffs are capacitated.

In 2015 different sessions took place to capacitate community cohesion leadership committees, women groups and youth. The community cohesion working groups had different meetings: end of session meetings (3 & 20 Feb, 270 & 300 participants); about natural resource use (23 Feb & 21 March, 238 & 253 participants); working group meetings (7-9 May and 11-13 May, 38 & 380 participants) and a awareness creation meeting (2-3 June, 40 participants). The Peace facilitators have been trained in February: 7 in Akobo and 4 in Wanthoa. Next to that dissemination and agreement ceremonies took place (March 25 - April 6, 235 participants and 28-30 April, 174 participants). At least 4 Justice Bureau staff were involved in all activities.
Relationships built with the Nuer Christian Youth Association. Will be worked upon further by the JB in 2014 - 2016.

description.narrative: Inclusive improved food security through increased availability and optimal and collaborative use of available livelihood resources and increased services among the various tribes and clans living in the targeted areasi, with special attention for the role of women and of youth.

By the end of the project, access to a safe and reliable source of drinking water has increased by 30% among 37.800 beneficiaries (5.400 households) in target areas of Pibor County; and among 8.000 beneficiaries (1.000 households) in the Woredas of Akobo and Wanthoa.

comment.narrative: 14% of the people have access to water through hand pumps and piped water during the rainy season, 13% have access during the dry season.

0% improvement; Drilling was started but not successful in 2014. Temporary solution was set up by the help of UNICEF through Emergency Water Systems. A feasibility study needs to show what the most cost efficient alternative solution will be for reaching our objective.

4 water boreholes are dug in Wanthoa in 4 different Kebeles in 2014. In Akobo two EMWAT systems are still running. It is now not possible to make water pumps in Akobo. Therefore water filters are bought are given for free to the most vulnerable. In Wanthoa the Water Department said there is a water point every 8 km in the Woreda. That means 100% of the people has access to safe drinking water.
Outcome indicator cannot be measured after year 1

description.narrative: At least 80% of the 1,000 + 1,000 beneficiary households show improvement in Food Consumption Score with 10 points over the baseline.

comment.narrative: Food Consumption Score is 27.7
Food Consumption Score is 30.7 which is 3 points over the baseline

Food Consumption Score is 49.56, which is 21.86 points over baseline score. Since the FCS is not measured per person, it is not known if 80% of 1,000 beneficiary households show improvement but we can estimate that this is the case.
Outcome indicator cannot be measured after year 1

description.narrative: Increased access to safe water and to education

By the end of the project, the percentage of households that use water from hand pumps as the primary source of household water consumption has increased by at least 10% In Pibor locality and 30% in Wanthoa and Akobo Woredas

comment.narrative: Jikany Nuer: 25% during rainy season and 21% during dry season; Anyuak: 0%.
10% increase in Pibor locality / 30% increase in Wanthoa and Akobo woredas (compared to baseline)

Pibor: 62% use hand pumps or piped water during the dry season. 58% use hand pumps or piped water during the rainy season. Wanthoa/Akobo: 40% use hand pump during the dry season, 38% use hand pump during the rainy season
10% increase in Pibor locality / 30% increase in Wanthoa and Akobo woredas (compared to baseline)
10% increase in Pibor locality / 30% increase in Wanthoa and Akobo woredas (compared to baseline)

description.narrative: At end of the program 50% of vocational trainees from the targeted Woreda capacitated to earn income from their acquired skills

comment.narrative: N/A

29 Teacher of Trainers who were trained in 2014 are still functioning (15 from Wanthoa + 6 IDPs from Akobo, 10 from Akobo). In 2015 they trained 164 VSTs in Wanthoa and 164 VSTs in Akobo. Recently the trainees got their start up material, in December 2015. Vocational skill trainees are trained. Not clear how many of them earn income from their acquired skills. It has been confirmed in interviews and FGDs that many of them do.

In 2014 32 people were trained to function as trainer for the rest of their community. For BUZA 180 beneficaries for the vocational skills training under this project are selected to be trained in 2015/2016
Selection process for a training centre was started.

description.narrative: Two Water Departments capacitated through technical assistance and training.

comment.narrative: N/A
In 2014 funded by EKN in Wanthoa 4 Water Committees are esablished and trained; The two water departement are planned to be trained by external or ZOA wash expert in 2015 under BUZA project.
In both Akobo and Wanthoa the Water Department received training in 2015. No other assistance.
The operation linked to water drilling will be implemented within the first and second quarters of the year 2014.

description.narrative: Two schools reconstructed and establishment of PTAs

comment.narrative: NA; 57% of respondents has school in village and 66% of respondents reported that thier children attend school (combined figures for both people groups).

One school is constructed in Burebey (Wanthoa), one is constructed in Tergol (Akobo). Both schools have a PTA which are functional. 611 (392 Male, 219 Female) students are enrolled in Burebey, 732 (612 Male, 120 Female) students are enrolled in Tergol.
Two schools are under construction, one in Akobo and one in Burbey. PTA's will be established in 2015.

description.narrative: Increased level of implementation of local agreements, decreased dowry levels and increased mutual respect and cooperation in various projects among the tribes and clans living in the targeted areas of Gambella with special attention for the role of women and youth.
In the targeted areas, 70% of the action points flowing from five local/regional agreements are actively follow up on, with focus on active participation of youth.

comment.narrative: N/A

70% is not measurable. In general it can be said that there are 4 agreements (2 community cohesion agreements, 2 natural resource agreements) and that the bylaws of the agreements are actively followed up on by the CCLC's and Community Cohesion Facilitators. Youth are involved in the whole process.

In 2014 (funded by USAID): 12 kebeles signed local community cohesion agreements and bylaws are in place. BUZA/EKN activities start in 2015 in 32 additional kebeles using experiences of 2014 community cohesion work with the USAID funding.
Not measurable after year 1

description.narrative: By the end of the project, at least 30% of the targeted beneficiaries indicate an improvement in their perception of shared identity and shared values with other groups.

comment.narrative: Outcome indicator, not measurable after year 1
Value is 1.44 on scale -2 to 2. This is an increase of 0.06 points over baseline value. This is an increase of approximately 4%.
Value is 1.79 on a five points scale. This is an increase of 30%.

description.narrative: Increased opportunities for positive inter-tribe/clan interaction on livelihood related matters, community cohesion, dowry reduction, sports.

By the end of the project 11 projects proposed and being implemented that promote inclusion and mutual respect. These projects must require inter-tribe/clan interaction and can deal with matters such as access to water, grazing land, trust building or campaigns aimed at making dowry prices and/or debts more manageable.

comment.narrative: N/A
6 in Wanthoa and 6 in Akobo are inter-tribe and inter-clan. They are Vegetable and Fishery groups (6/6) and know about the resource agreements and respect them.
Community conversations held and community cohesion (CC) faciliators were selected. 12 in Akobo Woreda and 12 in Wanthoa Woreda. These CC facilitators must be recognized by the JB.

In Akobo one fishing group and one fishing & vegetable group were setup consisting of Anywaa and Nuer members; In Wanthoa one fishing group, one fishing & vegetable group and one vegetable were established. From the last three it is unknown if these consist of members of different clans/ tribes. Will be sorted out in 2015.

description.narrative: By the end of the project 6 inter-tribe/clan sports competitions held.

comment.narrative: N/A
Fourteen sport teams organized and supported with materials, of which six soccer teams, six volleyball teams and two basketball teams.

In Wanthoa 2 sport competitions were held before 2015 and 1 in 2015. In Akobo 2 competitions have been organised, 16 sport teams in total are set up in Akobo in different age groups for volleyball, football and basketball.

One big sports competition was held in Wanthoa woreda; people from different clans/ tribes showed up to watch the soccer games that were played among the sports teams that are built up by youth from different clans and tribes
